l literals must be stored in a

 called "tyranny" and is bound

Abo=

y clever when you write your tests).

ting your system

ck-framework

ot be your's but you may have to change them when refactoring

 If you don't like

ow this can be

if you until you like it and whith rMock and EasyMock you can

 point later when I know more about the system I'm

 created an interface.

Wh=

I =

eadable until someone explains to them why jMock is more

I think that EasyMock can allo=
w for a bit too much messyness, that is

ict and forces you to express

g you with all the

RMock  also looks more like jMock when modifying method=

If i had to choose between jMock and EasyMoc=
k I'm not sure what I

bably be EasyMock

t that have
no requirements that some parts should run in earlier versions =
of
Java...

Throwing rMock into the picture I would pick it for at least th=
e
following reasons (except that I am involved in developing it :) ):

* St=
rict workflow, all tests are forcecd to have the same structure.
* Sections=
 for structuring and requering order of your tests.
* INTERCEPT! I have rea=
lly started to love this feature, it is extremely useful.
* automatical ver=
ification, no way around it, you cannot forget
verifying your mocks even if=
 you want to
* easy asserts for exceptions.

 think EasyMock and JMock provide nice

give you more context to be able

t out of the box (I think jMock has this feature aswell)

ibing
